position.marginalia_text: Aristomenes. Pliny. L.ii.c.37. writeth that Aristomenes, by his suttle Stratagemes, and warlike shiftes (being alance) did putt to flighte whole bandes of men. An argume[n]t as wel of his craftines, and suttelty, as of his excelle[n]s, and wonderfull fortitude. After he had slaine CCC. Lacedemonians, he was by the once, or twise taken captiue, and cast into pryson, but escapid [their] hands by creeping owte at A litle narrowe hoale in [the] prison; as Foxes, and Wesels doe. Being agayne taken he espied conuenient tyme, whe[n] his keepers, and Jaylers were well whitled w[i]th wine, and fast lulled; and then crawlid and rowlid himself to [the] fier; and there burning asunder [the] Cordes, and Gyuer, wherewith he was tyed, (togyther w[i]th [the] part of his body, where they were fastenid) escapid agayne. Being takin [the] third tyme, [the] Lacedemonians his Enemyes, meaning to make suer work with him, and desiring to see what was within him, ripped his brest, and fownd his Harte to be overgrowne with heare. Leuin[u]s Lemnius L.1. de [E[.]ples Alciate in his Emblemes, under [the] name of Aristomenes, commendith Charles [the] fifte.

emphasis.text: Alciate in his Emblemes, under [the] name of Aristomenes, commendith Charles [the] fifte.

position.marginalia_text: Adrianus Papa dixebat: Curia Dominorum, est Probatoria Meritorum.
Moses, & Dauid, imploy notes abowt [their] affaires, but only men of approouid actiuity, & hability. The manner of Princes, & States at this day.
Ex fruitibus eoru[m], cognoscetis eos. Nulla Mundi a[e]tas, tam Empirica, Pragmatica, Cosmopolitica, Mechanica, Chrematistica.

emphasis.text: tam Empirica, Pragmatica, Cosmopolitica, Mechanica, Chrematistica.

marginalia.translation: Pope Adrian said: 'The court of lords, is the one who approves of merits.' "By their fruits you will know them." No lifetime of the world is so empirical, pragmatic, cosmopolitan, mechanic, and enriching.

position.marginalia_text: Parùm sepulta[e] distat Inertia[e] Celata Virtus. Quid boni, ex Thesauro abscondito? Docosophia, et Euschemosyne. Sic luraet Lux uestra.

X-ref.text: Parum sepultae distat Inertiae celata virtus.

marginalia.translation: "Concealed virtue differs but little from buried idleness." What good things from the hidden treasure chamber are there? Wisdom and refinement. "So let your light shine."

marginalia.translation:
I. Sophocles. But he who boldly endures danger, neither language nor mind is in the habit to waver him.
Menander.
By no means any goddess is more illustrious than courage.
Euripides.
Can he, who is a coward, ever approach the greatest matters?
Sofitheus.
"One eagle routs the greatest flock of birds; one noble man routs many spiritless people."
Euripides.
"A fearful man is in no rank in battle, but he, although he is present, nevertheless is absent."
Moschion.
"A vast pile of leaves is cut in leaps with an small sword and a few people subdue numerous spears." Of a doubtful author from Greece. They are recited by Lucian from his 'Tragedies'.
"The unworthy matter is to charge a bothersome person with a vigorous attack into men by bloodshed so that it swells out. Hostile spears fear armed men."
"A stronger life is not the way to courage." Menander.
No boldness is a more powerful or more magnificent provision.

position.marginalia_text: { E gra[e]co Eueni. Cu[m] prudente juuat permultu[m] Audatia Mente; Mente earens, multis est ea causa malis.

marginalia.translation: From the Greek Evenus. Very many people help with a prudent and bold mind; for many people, lacking a mind is the cause of evil.

position.marginalia_text: Amor sine Audatia est carmen Lugubre.

marginalia.translation: Love without courage is a mournful song.

X-ref.text: Verus Amor nullum nouit habere modum.

marginalia.translation: True love knows to have no limit.
To enjoy others [is] to enjoy yourself.
